name: Major Cyber Attacks
description: Exploring the most impactful cyber attacks in history, their techniques, and their consequences.

cards.title: The Morris Worm (1988)
cards.description: The first large-scale self-replicating computer worm, infecting 10% of ARPANET (Advanced Research Projects Agency Network), an early version of the internet.
bulletpoints: Written by Robert Tappan Morris, a Cornell University student.
Exploit: Buffer overflow and weak password security.
First felony conviction under the U.S. Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.
cards.summaryText: Recall the Morris Worm’s runaway spread and the landmark CFAA conviction that followed.

cards.title: The Melissa Virus (1999)
cards.description: One of the first email-borne macro viruses, spreading through Microsoft Word documents and causing email servers to overload.
bulletpoints: Created by David L. Smith, named after an exotic dancer.
Exploit: Microsoft Word macro vulnerabilities.
Infected over 100,000 computers, including U.S. government and corporate networks.
cards.summaryText: See how Melissa’s weaponized macros choked email servers worldwide.

cards.title: ILOVEYOU Worm (2000)
cards.description: A destructive email virus that spread via an attachment titled 'ILOVEYOU.txt.vbs', tricking users into opening a Visual Basic script.
bulletpoints: Created by Onel de Guzman in the Philippines.
Exploit: Social engineering and Windows scripting vulnerabilities.
Infected over 50 million computers and caused $15 billion in damages.
cards.summaryText: Remember ILOVEYOU’s social engineering bomb and the billions it burned.

cards.title: Stuxnet (2010)
cards.description: A sophisticated cyber-weapon, designed to sabotage Iran's nuclear centrifuges using a targeted malware attack on industrial control systems.
bulletpoints: Jointly developed by the United States and Israel.
Exploit: Zero-day vulnerabilities in Microsoft Windows and Siemens SCADA (Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition) systems.
First publicly known instance of cyber warfare targeting physical infrastructure.
cards.summaryText: Study Stuxnet’s multi-zero-day kit crippling Iran’s centrifuges in the first kinetic cyber strike.

cards.title: Sony PlayStation Network Breach (2011)
cards.description: A data breach in Sony's PlayStation Network (PSN) exposed the personal information of 77 million users.
bulletpoints: Exploit: Unpatched web server vulnerabilities.
Hackers stole names, addresses, passwords, and credit card details.
Led to a 23-day shutdown of PlayStation Network services.
cards.summaryText: Review the PSN breach that exposed 77 million gamers and forced a weeks-long shutdown.

cards.title: The LinkedIn Data Breach (2012)
cards.description: A cyber attack exposed hashed passwords of 6.5 million LinkedIn users.
bulletpoints: Exploit: Unsalted SHA-1 password hashing, making decryption easier.
Passwords were leaked on Russian hacker forums.
Later, in 2016, 167 million more accounts were found to be compromised.
cards.summaryText: See LinkedIn’s weak hashing leak snowball into a 167-million-account exposure.

cards.title: Yahoo Data Breach (2013-2014)
cards.description: The largest known data breach in history, affecting all 3 billion Yahoo accounts.
bulletpoints: Exploit: Phishing and poor encryption security.
Personal data, including emails, passwords, and security questions, were compromised.
Resulted in Yahoo reducing its acquisition value in a Verizon buyout.
cards.summaryText: Recall Yahoo’s 3-billion-account breach and the valuation hit it triggered.

cards.title: Ukraine Power Grid Attack (2015-2016)
cards.description: The first known successful cyber attack to disable a power grid, causing massive blackouts in Ukraine.
bulletpoints: Exploit: Spear-phishing emails and BlackEnergy malware.
Shutdown affected over 230,000 people.
Attributed to Russian state-sponsored hackers.
cards.summaryText: Analyze how BlackEnergy dropped Ukraine’s grid and signaled modern cyber warfare.

cards.title: Equifax Data Breach (2017)
cards.description: A massive security breach at Equifax, exposing personal data of 147 million people, including Social Security numbers and credit histories.
bulletpoints: Exploit: Unpatched Apache Struts vulnerability (CVE-2017-5638).
Hackers accessed sensitive financial data for over two months.
Equifax was fined $700 million in settlements.
cards.summaryText: Trace Equifax’s missed patch to the 147-million-person data disaster.

cards.title: WannaCry Ransomware (2017)
cards.description: A global ransomware attack that infected over 230,000 computers across 150 countries, encrypting files and demanding Bitcoin payments.
bulletpoints: Exploit: EternalBlue vulnerability in Microsoft Windows (leaked from NSA tools).
Hospitals, businesses, and government agencies were impacted.
A researcher, Marcus Hutchins, accidentally stopped the attack by registering a kill switch domain.
cards.summaryText: Follow WannaCry’s EternalBlue rampage and the lucky kill-switch save.

cards.title: NotPetya Cyber Attack (2017)
cards.description: A destructive malware attack disguised as ransomware, causing an estimated $10 billion in damages worldwide.
bulletpoints: Exploit: Windows SMBv1 vulnerability (same as WannaCry).
Originated in Ukraine but spread globally, hitting Maersk, FedEx, and other companies.
Believed to be Russian state-sponsored cyber warfare.
cards.summaryText: Compare NotPetya’s faux ransomware guise with the destructive wave it unleashed worldwide.

cards.title: SolarWinds Supply Chain Attack (2020)
cards.description: A sophisticated supply chain attack that compromised U.S. government agencies and Fortune 500 companies.
bulletpoints: Exploit: Malicious code inserted into SolarWinds Orion IT management software.
Used to infiltrate Microsoft, FireEye, and U.S. federal agencies.
Believed to be an advanced persistent threat (APT) linked to Russian intelligence.
cards.summaryText: Dissect SolarWinds’ supply-chain compromise and the APT access it granted.

cards.title: Colonial Pipeline Ransomware Attack (2021)
cards.description: A ransomware attack on the Colonial Pipeline disrupted the fuel supply in the United States.
bulletpoints: Exploit: Password reuse and VPN vulnerabilities.
Attackers from DarkSide ransomware group demanded a Bitcoin ransom.
Led to fuel shortages and government intervention in cyber policy.
cards.summaryText: Review Colonial Pipeline’s ransomware hit, fuel disruptions, and policy wake-up call.
